did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: City of Winchester, Public Buildings and Grounds, City Water Works Pipe Sketches, 1894

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Public Buildings and Grounds, Water Works Pipe Sketches, 1894. Local government records collection, City of Winchester (Va.) Court Records. The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Va. 23219.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This item came to the Library of Virginia in shipments of court papers from Winchester (Va.).

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: City of Winchester, in Frederick County was first known as Opequon, then as Frederick's Town (or Fredericktown), and, finally, upon establishment as a town in 1752, as Winchester. According to tradition, one of the town's founders, James Wood, named the town in honor of his birthplace in England. Winchester was incorporated as a town in 1779 and as a city in 1874. It was enlarged by annexation from Frederick County in 1970.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: City of Winchester (Va.) Public Buildings and Grounds, Water Works Pipe Sketches, 1894, includes nine sheets depicting street layouts and underlying city water mains, pipes, hydrants, and blow-off valves.
